question.short: What is the origin of the SARS-CoV-2 virus?
question.long: What is the origin of the SARS-CoV-2 virus?

description: Results from studies trying to determine how the COVID-19 pandemic started.

no_consensus.description: The literature has not yet reached a consensus on the origin of the SARS-CoV-2 virus

animal_transmission.description: The literature suggests that the SARS-CoV-2 virus was transmitted from animals to humans

towards_animal_transmission.description: The literature suggests that the SARS-CoV-2 virus was probably transmitted from animals to humans, but more research is needed

towards_lab_leak.description: The literature suggests that the SARS-CoV-2 virus may have originated from a laboratory leak, but more research is needed

lab_leak.description: The literature suggests that the SARS-CoV-2 virus originated from a laboratory leak

animal_transmission.description: The results of the paper suggest that the SARS-CoV-2 virus was transmitted from animals to humans

animal_transmission_unlike_literature.description: The results of the paper suggest that the SARS-CoV-2 virus was probably transmitted from animals to humans, unlike what is reported in the literature

animal_transmission_but_low_confidence.description: The results of the paper suggest that the SARS-CoV-2 virus was probably transmitted from animals to humans, but the evidence is not strong

animal_transmission_but_mixed.description: The results of the paper suggest that the SARS-CoV-2 virus was probably transmitted from animals to humans, but the evidence is mixed

mixed.description: The results of the paper cannot determine the origin of the SARS-CoV-2 virus

no_results.description: There is not enough evidence to determine the origin of the SARS-CoV-2 virus

lab_leak_but_mixed.description: The results of the paper suggest that the SARS-CoV-2 virus may have originated from a laboratory leak, but the evidence is mixed

lab_leak_but_low_confidence.description: The results of the paper suggest that the SARS-CoV-2 virus may have originated from a laboratory leak, but the evidence is not strong

lab_leak_unlike_literature.description: The results of the paper suggest that the SARS-CoV-2 virus may have originated from a laboratory leak, unlike what is reported in the literature

lab_leak.description: The results of the paper suggest that the SARS-CoV-2 virus may have originated from a laboratory leak

papers.title: A new coronavirus associated with human respiratory disease in China
papers.quote: Although SARS-like viruses have been identified widely in bats in China, viruses identical to SARS-CoV have not yet been documented. Notably, WHCV is most closely related to bat coronaviruses, and shows 100% amino acid similarity to bat SL CoVZC45 in the nsp7 and E proteins. Thus, these data suggest that bats are a possible host for the viral reservoir of WHCV

papers.title: A pneumonia outbreak associated with a new coronavirus of probable bat origin
papers.quote: The close phylogenetic relationship to RaTG13 provides evidence that 2019-nCoV may have originated in bats

notes.title: Wuhan Institute of Virology
notes.description: This paper comes from the Wuhan Institute of Virology, which is precisely the same laboratory that will later be accused of having leaked the virus

papers.title: Identifying SARS-CoV-2-related coronaviruses in Malayan pangolins
papers.quote: Here we report the identification of SARS-CoV-2-related coronaviruses in Malayan pangolins (Manis javanica) seized in anti-smuggling operations in southern China. Metagenomic sequencing identified pangolin associated coronaviruses that belong to two sub-lineages of SARS-CoV-2-related coronaviruses, including one that exhibits strong similarity in the receptor-binding domain to SARS-CoV-2. The Discovery of multiple lineages of pangolin coronavirus and their similarity to SARS-CoV-2 suggests that pangolins should be considered as possible hosts in the emergence of new coronaviruses and should be removed from wet markets to prevent zoonotic transmission

papers.title: Isolation of SARS-CoV-2-related coronavirus from Malayan pangolins
papers.quote: The isolation of a coronavirus from pangolins that is closely related to SARS-CoV-2 suggests that these animals have the potential to act as an intermediate host of SARS-CoV-2. This newly identified coronavirus from pangolins‚Äîthe most-trafficked mammal in the illegal wildlife trade‚Äîcould represent a future threat to public health if wildlife trade is not effectively controlled

papers.title: Might SARS‚ÄêCoV‚Äê2 Have Arisen via Serial Passage through an Animal Host or Cell Culture?
papers.quote: Taken together, the available evidence does not point definitively toward a natural origin for SARS-CoV-2, rather, much of it is more consistent with what would be found if the novel coronavirus had arisen from serial passage of a "precursor" progenitor virus in a lab

notes.title: No direct genetic / epidemiologic evidence
notes.description: The paper advances a lab-related hypothesis largely by plausibility and analogy to previous incidents, without presenting direct genetic / epidemiologic evidence for SARS-CoV-2

papers.title: Natural selection versus creation: a literature review on the origin of SARS-CoV-2
papers.quote: The information and knowledge currently available in the public domain as peer-reviewed publications support a probable bat or pangolin origin of SARS-CoV-2

papers.title: The genetic structure of SARS‚ÄêCoV‚Äê2 does not rule out a laboratory origin
papers.quote: We here describe how the two main SARSCoV-2 features [...] might be the result of lab manipulation techniques such as site-directed mutagenesis. The acquisition of both unique features by SARS-CoV-2 more or less simultaneously is less likely to be natural or caused only by cell/animal serial passage

papers.title: The proximal origin of SARS-CoV-2
papers.quote: Our analyses clearly show that SARS-CoV-2 is not a laboratory construct or a purposefully manipulated virus

papers.title: A novel SARS-CoV-2 related coronavirus in bats from Cambodia
papers.quote: The data presented here further indicate that SARS-CoV-2 related viruses have a much wider geographic distribution than previously understood, and likely circulate via multiple Rhinolophus species. [...] Finally, pangolins, as well as members of order Carnivora, especially the Viverridae5, Mustelidae6, and Felidae7 families are readily susceptible to SARS-CoV-2 infection, might represent intermediary hosts for transmission to humans, and should not be ignored in future surveillance efforts in the region. Viruses of the SARS-CoV-2 sublineage, with one exhibiting strong sequence similarity to SARS-CoV-2 in the RBD, were recently detected in distinct groups of pangolins seized during anti-smuggling operations in southeast China

papers.title: Investigate the origins of COVID-19
papers.quote: There were no findings in clear support of either a natural spillover or a lab accident

papers.title: The origins of SARS-CoV-2: A critical review
papers.quote: As for the vast majority of human viruses, the most parsimonious explanation for the origin of SARS-CoV-2 is a zoonotic event. The documented epidemiological history of the virus is comparable to previous animal market-associated outbreaks of coronaviruses with a simple route for human exposure

papers.title: What we know and what we need to know about the origin of SARS-CoV-2
papers.quote: Most papers here reviewed point in the direction of a zoonotic origin, an origin in which horseshoe bats from the species Rhinolophus affinis seemed to be a natural reservoir, while pangolins (Manis javanica) could be an intermediate host of the coronavirus. However, even considering the zoonotic hypothesis as the most likely, today, the intermediate source species of SARS-CoV-2 has not been confirmed. On the other hand, although some researchers clearly point to an unnatural origin of SARS-CoV-2, their conclusions are not strongly based on a strict scientific evidence, being largely speculative

papers.title: WHO-convened global study of origins of SARS-CoV-2: China Part
papers.quote: The joint team‚Äôs assessment of likelihood of each possible pathway was as follows: ‚Ä¢ direct zoonotic spillover is considered to be a possible-to-likely pathway ‚Ä¢ introduction through an intermediate host is considered to be a likely to very likely pathway ‚Ä¢ introduction through cold/ food chain products is considered a possible pathway ‚Ä¢ introduction through a laboratory incident was considered to be an extremely unlikely pathway

notes.title: Transparency in Chinese cooperation
notes.description: Chinese data lacks transparency, limiting independent access
